Table of Contents

Understanding Mouth Shapes

FaceToons supports a standardized set of 6 basic mouth shapes, along with 3 extended shapes, following the standard developed by Hanna-Barbera studios in the 1960s. This set has since become the industry standard for TV animation. These shapes are mapped to indices 0-8 in any MouthCollection intended for LipSync or MouthShape clips.

Additional shapes can be used for more expressive animation, but these will need to be indexed by number rather than shape and are not supported by default lip-sync tools. It is recommended to either use indexes outside of the MouthShape range for additional poses or package more textures into a single Mouth Frame.

Mouth Reference

Mouth Shape Image Description
Ⓐ Closed mouth for the "P", "B", and "M" sounds. This is nearly identical to the Ⓧ shape but with slight pressure between the lips.
Ⓑ Slightly open mouth with clenched teeth, used for most consonants ("K", "S", "T", etc.) and some vowels like "EE" as in bee.
Ⓒ Open mouth, used for vowels like "EH" in men and "AE" in bat. Also serves as an in-between shape when transitioning from Ⓐ or Ⓑ to Ⓓ.
Ⓓ Wide open mouth, used for "AA" as in father.
Ⓔ Slightly rounded mouth, used for "AO" in off and "ER" in bird. Also an in-between when moving from Ⓒ or Ⓓ to Ⓕ. Ensure ⒸⒺⒻ and ⒹⒺⒻ transitions are smooth, with Ⓔ not opening wider than Ⓒ.
Ⓕ Puckered lips, used for "UW" as in you, "OW" in show, and "W" in way.

Extended Shapes

Mouth Shape Image Description
Ⓖ Upper teeth touching the lower lip, used for "F" in for and "V" in very. Optional but recommended for added realism if the style allows.
Ⓗ Long "L" sounds, with the tongue raised behind the upper teeth. The mouth should be at least as open as Ⓒ but not as wide as Ⓓ. Optional based on art style; if the tongue is not visible, this shape may be unnecessary.
Ⓧ Idle position for pauses in speech. Nearly identical to Ⓐ but with relaxed, lightly closed lips. Optional; whether Ⓧ differs from Ⓐ depends on your style and taste.
Made with docfx
